fs.c

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 // File system implementation.  Five layers:
00002 //   + Blocks: allocator for raw disk blocks.
00003 //   + Log: crash recovery for multi-step updates.
00004 //   + Files: inode allocator, reading, writing, metadata.
00005 //   + Directories: inode with special contents (list of other inodes!)
00006 //   + Names: paths like /usr/rtm/xv6/fs.c for convenient naming.
00007 //
00008 // This file contains the low-level file system manipulation 
00009 // routines.  The (higher-level) system call implementations
00010 // are in sysfile.c.
00011 
00012 #include "types.h"
00013 #include "defs.h"
00014 #include "param.h"
00015 #include "stat.h"
00016 #include "mmu.h"
00017 #include "proc.h"
00018 #include "spinlock.h"
00019 #include "buf.h"
00020 #include "fs.h"
00021 #include "file.h"

00023 #define min(a, b) ((a) < (b) ? (a) : (b))
00024 static void itrunc(struct inode*);

00026 // Read the super block.
00027 void
00028 readsb(int dev, struct superblock *sb)
00029 {
00030   struct buf *bp;
00031   
00032   bp = bread(dev, 1);
00033   memmove(sb, bp->data, sizeof(*sb));
00034   brelse(bp);
00035 }
00036 
00037 // Zero a block.
00038 static void
00039 bzero(int dev, int bno)
00040 {
00041   struct buf *bp;
00042   
00043   bp = bread(dev, bno);
00044   memset(bp->data, 0, BSIZE);
00045   log_write(bp);
00046   brelse(bp);
00047 }
00048 
00049 // Blocks. 
00050 
00051 // Allocate a zeroed disk block.
00052 static uint
00053 balloc(uint dev)
00054 {
00055   int b, bi, m;
00056   struct buf *bp;
00057   struct superblock sb;
00058 
00059   bp = 0;
00060   readsb(dev, &sb);
00061   for(b = 0; b < sb.size; b += BPB){
00062     bp = bread(dev, BBLOCK(b, sb.ninodes));
00063     for(bi = 0; bi < BPB && b + bi < sb.size; bi++){
00064       m = 1 << (bi % 8);
00065       if((bp->data[bi/8] & m) == 0){  // Is block free?
00066         bp->data[bi/8] |= m;  // Mark block in use.
00067         log_write(bp);
00068         brelse(bp);
00069         bzero(dev, b + bi);
00070         return b + bi;
00071       }
00072     }
00073     brelse(bp);
00074   }
00075   panic("balloc: out of blocks");
00076 }
00077 
00078 // Free a disk block.
00079 static void
00080 bfree(int dev, uint b)
00081 {
00082   struct buf *bp;
00083   struct superblock sb;
00084   int bi, m;
00085 
00086   readsb(dev, &sb);
00087   bp = bread(dev, BBLOCK(b, sb.ninodes));
00088   bi = b % BPB;
00089   m = 1 << (bi % 8);
00090   if((bp->data[bi/8] & m) == 0)
00091     panic("freeing free block");
00092   bp->data[bi/8] &= ~m;
00093   log_write(bp);
00094   brelse(bp);
00095 }
00096 
00097 // Inodes.
00098 //
00099 // An inode describes a single unnamed file.
00100 // The inode disk structure holds metadata: the file's type,
00101 // its size, the number of links referring to it, and the
00102 // list of blocks holding the file's content.
00103 //
00104 // The inodes are laid out sequentially on disk immediately after
00105 // the superblock. Each inode has a number, indicating its
00106 // position on the disk.
00107 //
00108 // The kernel keeps a cache of in-use inodes in memory
00109 // to provide a place for synchronizing access
00110 // to inodes used by multiple processes. The cached
00111 // inodes include book-keeping information that is
00112 // not stored on disk: ip->ref and ip->flags.
00113 //
00114 // An inode and its in-memory represtative go through a
00115 // sequence of states before they can be used by the
00116 // rest of the file system code.
00117 //
00118 // * Allocation: an inode is allocated if its type (on disk)
00119 //   is non-zero. ialloc() allocates, iput() frees if
00120 //   the link count has fallen to zero.
00121 //
00122 // * Referencing in cache: an entry in the inode cache
00123 //   is free if ip->ref is zero. Otherwise ip->ref tracks
00124 //   the number of in-memory pointers to the entry (open
00125 //   files and current directories). iget() to find or
00126 //   create a cache entry and increment its ref, iput()
00127 //   to decrement ref.
00128 //
00129 // * Valid: the information (type, size, &c) in an inode
00130 //   cache entry is only correct when the I_VALID bit
00131 //   is set in ip->flags. ilock() reads the inode from
00132 //   the disk and sets I_VALID, while iput() clears
00133 //   I_VALID if ip->ref has fallen to zero.
00134 //
00135 // * Locked: file system code may only examine and modify
00136 //   the information in an inode and its content if it
00137 //   has first locked the inode. The I_BUSY flag indicates
00138 //   that the inode is locked. ilock() sets I_BUSY,
00139 //   while iunlock clears it.
00140 //
00141 // Thus a typical sequence is:
00142 //   ip = iget(dev, inum)
00143 //   ilock(ip)
00144 //   ... examine and modify ip->xxx ...
00145 //   iunlock(ip)
00146 //   iput(ip)
00147 //
00148 // ilock() is separate from iget() so that system calls can
00149 // get a long-term reference to an inode (as for an open file)
00150 // and only lock it for short periods (e.g., in read()).
00151 // The separation also helps avoid deadlock and races during
00152 // pathname lookup. iget() increments ip->ref so that the inode
00153 // stays cached and pointers to it remain valid.
00154 //
00155 // Many internal file system functions expect the caller to
00156 // have locked the inodes involved; this lets callers create
00157 // multi-step atomic operations.
00158 
00159 struct {
00160   struct spinlock lock;
00161   struct inode inode[NINODE];
00162 } icache;
00163 
00164 void
00165 iinit(void)
00166 {
00167   initlock(&icache.lock, "icache");
00168 }
00169 
00170 static struct inode* iget(uint dev, uint inum);
00171 
00172 //PAGEBREAK!
00173 // Allocate a new inode with the given type on device dev.
00174 // A free inode has a type of zero.
00175 struct inode*
00176 ialloc(uint dev, short type)
00177 {
00178   int inum;
00179   struct buf *bp;
00180   struct dinode *dip;
00181   struct superblock sb;
00182 
00183   readsb(dev, &sb);
00184 
00185   for(inum = 1; inum < sb.ninodes; inum++){
00186     bp = bread(dev, IBLOCK(inum));
00187     dip = (struct dinode*)bp->data + inum%IPB;
00188     if(dip->type == 0){  // a free inode
00189       memset(dip, 0, sizeof(*dip));
00190       dip->type = type;
00191       log_write(bp);   // mark it allocated on the disk
00192       brelse(bp);
00193       return iget(dev, inum);
00194     }
00195     brelse(bp);
00196   }
00197   panic("ialloc: no inodes");
00198 }
00199 
00200 // Copy a modified in-memory inode to disk.
00201 void
00202 iupdate(struct inode *ip)
00203 {
00204   struct buf *bp;
00205   struct dinode *dip;
00206 
00207   bp = bread(ip->dev, IBLOCK(ip->inum));
00208   dip = (struct dinode*)bp->data + ip->inum%IPB;
00209   dip->type = ip->type;
00210   dip->major = ip->major;
00211   dip->minor = ip->minor;
00212   dip->nlink = ip->nlink;
00213   dip->size = ip->size;
00214   memmove(dip->addrs, ip->addrs, sizeof(ip->addrs));
00215   log_write(bp);
00216   brelse(bp);
00217 }
00218 
00219 // Find the inode with number inum on device dev
00220 // and return the in-memory copy. Does not lock
00221 // the inode and does not read it from disk.
00222 static struct inode*
00223 iget(uint dev, uint inum)
00224 {
00225   struct inode *ip, *empty;
00226 
00227   acquire(&icache.lock);
00228 
00229   // Is the inode already cached?
00230   empty = 0;
00231   for(ip = &icache.inode[0]; ip < &icache.inode[NINODE]; ip++){
00232     if(ip->ref > 0 && ip->dev == dev && ip->inum == inum){
00233       ip->ref++;
00234       release(&icache.lock);
00235       return ip;
00236     }
00237     if(empty == 0 && ip->ref == 0)    // Remember empty slot.
00238       empty = ip;
00239   }
00240 
00241   // Recycle an inode cache entry.
00242   if(empty == 0)
00243     panic("iget: no inodes");
00244 
00245   ip = empty;
00246   ip->dev = dev;
00247   ip->inum = inum;
00248   ip->ref = 1;
00249   ip->flags = 0;
00250   release(&icache.lock);
00251 
00252   return ip;
00253 }
00254 
00255 // Increment reference count for ip.
00256 // Returns ip to enable ip = idup(ip1) idiom.
00257 struct inode*
00258 idup(struct inode *ip)
00259 {
00260   acquire(&icache.lock);
00261   ip->ref++;
00262   release(&icache.lock);
00263   return ip;
00264 }
00265 
00266 // Lock the given inode.
00267 // Reads the inode from disk if necessary.
00268 void
00269 ilock(struct inode *ip)
00270 {
00271   struct buf *bp;
00272   struct dinode *dip;
00273 
00274   if(ip == 0 || ip->ref < 1)
00275     panic("ilock");
00276 
00277   acquire(&icache.lock);
00278   while(ip->flags & I_BUSY)
00279     sleep(ip, &icache.lock);
00280   ip->flags |= I_BUSY;
00281   release(&icache.lock);
00282 
00283   if(!(ip->flags & I_VALID)){
00284     bp = bread(ip->dev, IBLOCK(ip->inum));
00285     dip = (struct dinode*)bp->data + ip->inum%IPB;
00286     ip->type = dip->type;
00287     ip->major = dip->major;
00288     ip->minor = dip->minor;
00289     ip->nlink = dip->nlink;
00290     ip->size = dip->size;
00291     memmove(ip->addrs, dip->addrs, sizeof(ip->addrs));
00292     brelse(bp);
00293     ip->flags |= I_VALID;
00294     if(ip->type == 0)
00295       panic("ilock: no type");
00296   }
00297 }
00298 
00299 // Unlock the given inode.
00300 void
00301 iunlock(struct inode *ip)
00302 {
00303   if(ip == 0 || !(ip->flags & I_BUSY) || ip->ref < 1)
00304     panic("iunlock");
00305 
00306   acquire(&icache.lock);
00307   ip->flags &= ~I_BUSY;
00308   wakeup(ip);
00309   release(&icache.lock);
00310 }
00311 
00312 // Drop a reference to an in-memory inode.
00313 // If that was the last reference, the inode cache entry can
00314 // be recycled.
00315 // If that was the last reference and the inode has no links
00316 // to it, free the inode (and its content) on disk.
00317 void
00318 iput(struct inode *ip)
00319 {
00320   acquire(&icache.lock);
00321   if(ip->ref == 1 && (ip->flags & I_VALID) && ip->nlink == 0){
00322     // inode has no links: truncate and free inode.
00323     if(ip->flags & I_BUSY)
00324       panic("iput busy");
00325     ip->flags |= I_BUSY;
00326     release(&icache.lock);
00327     itrunc(ip);
00328     ip->type = 0;
00329     iupdate(ip);
00330     acquire(&icache.lock);
00331     ip->flags = 0;
00332     wakeup(ip);
00333   }
00334   ip->ref--;
00335   release(&icache.lock);
00336 }
00337 
00338 // Common idiom: unlock, then put.
00339 void
00340 iunlockput(struct inode *ip)
00341 {
00342   iunlock(ip);
00343   iput(ip);
00344 }
00345 
00346 //PAGEBREAK!
00347 // Inode content
00348 //
00349 // The content (data) associated with each inode is stored
00350 // in blocks on the disk. The first NDIRECT block numbers
00351 // are listed in ip->addrs[].  The next NINDIRECT blocks are 
00352 // listed in block ip->addrs[NDIRECT].
00353 
00354 // Return the disk block address of the nth block in inode ip.
00355 // If there is no such block, bmap allocates one.
00356 static uint
00357 bmap(struct inode *ip, uint bn)
00358 {
00359   uint addr, *a;
00360   struct buf *bp;
00361 
00362   if(bn < NDIRECT){
00363     if((addr = ip->addrs[bn]) == 0)
00364       ip->addrs[bn] = addr = balloc(ip->dev);
00365     return addr;
00366   }
00367   bn -= NDIRECT;
00368 
00369   if(bn < NINDIRECT){
00370     // Load indirect block, allocating if necessary.
00371     if((addr = ip->addrs[NDIRECT]) == 0)
00372       ip->addrs[NDIRECT] = addr = balloc(ip->dev);
00373     bp = bread(ip->dev, addr);
00374     a = (uint*)bp->data;
00375     if((addr = a[bn]) == 0){
00376       a[bn] = addr = balloc(ip->dev);
00377       log_write(bp);
00378     }
00379     brelse(bp);
00380     return addr;
00381   }
00382 
00383   panic("bmap: out of range");
00384 }
00385 
00386 // Truncate inode (discard contents).
00387 // Only called when the inode has no links
00388 // to it (no directory entries referring to it)
00389 // and has no in-memory reference to it (is
00390 // not an open file or current directory).
00391 static void
00392 itrunc(struct inode *ip)
00393 {
00394   int i, j;
00395   struct buf *bp;
00396   uint *a;
00397 
00398   for(i = 0; i < NDIRECT; i++){
00399     if(ip->addrs[i]){
00400       bfree(ip->dev, ip->addrs[i]);
00401       ip->addrs[i] = 0;
00402     }
00403   }
00404   
00405   if(ip->addrs[NDIRECT]){
00406     bp = bread(ip->dev, ip->addrs[NDIRECT]);
00407     a = (uint*)bp->data;
00408     for(j = 0; j < NINDIRECT; j++){
00409       if(a[j])
00410         bfree(ip->dev, a[j]);
00411     }
00412     brelse(bp);
00413     bfree(ip->dev, ip->addrs[NDIRECT]);
00414     ip->addrs[NDIRECT] = 0;
00415   }
00416 
00417   ip->size = 0;
00418   iupdate(ip);
00419 }
00420 
00421 // Copy stat information from inode.
00422 void
00423 stati(struct inode *ip, struct stat *st)
00424 {
00425   st->dev = ip->dev;
00426   st->ino = ip->inum;
00427   st->type = ip->type;
00428   st->nlink = ip->nlink;
00429   st->size = ip->size;
00430 }
00431 
00432 //PAGEBREAK!
00433 // Read data from inode.
00434 int
00435 readi(struct inode *ip, char *dst, uint off, uint n)
00436 {
00437   uint tot, m;
00438   struct buf *bp;
00439 
00440   if(ip->type == T_DEV){
00441     if(ip->major < 0 || ip->major >= NDEV || !devsw[ip->major].read)
00442       return -1;
00443     return devsw[ip->major].read(ip, dst, n);
00444   }
00445 
00446   if(off > ip->size || off + n < off)
00447     return -1;
00448   if(off + n > ip->size)
00449     n = ip->size - off;
00450 
00451   for(tot=0; tot<n; tot+=m, off+=m, dst+=m){
00452     bp = bread(ip->dev, bmap(ip, off/BSIZE));
00453     m = min(n - tot, BSIZE - off%BSIZE);
00454     memmove(dst, bp->data + off%BSIZE, m);
00455     brelse(bp);
00456   }
00457   return n;
00458 }
00459 
00460 // PAGEBREAK!
00461 // Write data to inode.
00462 int
00463 writei(struct inode *ip, char *src, uint off, uint n)
00464 {
00465   uint tot, m;
00466   struct buf *bp;
00467 
00468   if(ip->type == T_DEV){
00469     if(ip->major < 0 || ip->major >= NDEV || !devsw[ip->major].write)
00470       return -1;
00471     return devsw[ip->major].write(ip, src, n);
00472   }
00473 
00474   if(off > ip->size || off + n < off)
00475     return -1;
00476   if(off + n > MAXFILE*BSIZE)
00477     return -1;
00478 
00479   for(tot=0; tot<n; tot+=m, off+=m, src+=m){
00480     bp = bread(ip->dev, bmap(ip, off/BSIZE));
00481     m = min(n - tot, BSIZE - off%BSIZE);
00482     memmove(bp->data + off%BSIZE, src, m);
00483     log_write(bp);
00484     brelse(bp);
00485   }
00486 
00487   if(n > 0 && off > ip->size){
00488     ip->size = off;
00489     iupdate(ip);
00490   }
00491   return n;
00492 }

00495 // Directories

00497 int
00498 namecmp(const char *s, const char *t)
00499 {
00500   return strncmp(s, t, DIRSIZ);
00501 }
00502 
00503 // Look for a directory entry in a directory.
00504 // If found, set *poff to byte offset of entry.
00505 struct inode*
00506 dirlookup(struct inode *dp, char *name, uint *poff)
00507 {
00508   uint off, inum;
00509   struct dirent de;
00510 
00511   if(dp->type != T_DIR)
00512     panic("dirlookup not DIR");
00513 
00514   for(off = 0; off < dp->size; off += sizeof(de)){
00515     if(readi(dp, (char*)&de, off, sizeof(de)) != sizeof(de))
00516       panic("dirlink read");
00517     if(de.inum == 0)
00518       continue;
00519     if(namecmp(name, de.name) == 0){
00520       // entry matches path element
00521       if(poff)
00522         *poff = off;
00523       inum = de.inum;
00524       return iget(dp->dev, inum);
00525     }
00526   }
00527 
00528   return 0;
00529 }
00530 
00531 // Write a new directory entry (name, inum) into the directory dp.
00532 int
00533 dirlink(struct inode *dp, char *name, uint inum)
00534 {
00535   int off;
00536   struct dirent de;
00537   struct inode *ip;
00538 
00539   // Check that name is not present.
00540   if((ip = dirlookup(dp, name, 0)) != 0){
00541     iput(ip);
00542     return -1;
00543   }
00544 
00545   // Look for an empty dirent.
00546   for(off = 0; off < dp->size; off += sizeof(de)){
00547     if(readi(dp, (char*)&de, off, sizeof(de)) != sizeof(de))
00548       panic("dirlink read");
00549     if(de.inum == 0)
00550       break;
00551   }
00552 
00553   strncpy(de.name, name, DIRSIZ);
00554   de.inum = inum;
00555   if(writei(dp, (char*)&de, off, sizeof(de)) != sizeof(de))
00556     panic("dirlink");
00557   
00558   return 0;
00559 }
00560 
00561 //PAGEBREAK!
00562 // Paths
00563 
00564 // Copy the next path element from path into name.
00565 // Return a pointer to the element following the copied one.
00566 // The returned path has no leading slashes,
00567 // so the caller can check *path=='\0' to see if the name is the last one.
00568 // If no name to remove, return 0.
00569 //
00570 // Examples:
00571 //   skipelem("a/bb/c", name) = "bb/c", setting name = "a"
00572 //   skipelem("///a//bb", name) = "bb", setting name = "a"
00573 //   skipelem("a", name) = "", setting name = "a"
00574 //   skipelem("", name) = skipelem("////", name) = 0
00575 //
00576 static char*
00577 skipelem(char *path, char *name)
00578 {
00579   char *s;
00580   int len;
00581 
00582   while(*path == '/')
00583     path++;
00584   if(*path == 0)
00585     return 0;
00586   s = path;
00587   while(*path != '/' && *path != 0)
00588     path++;
00589   len = path - s;
00590   if(len >= DIRSIZ)
00591     memmove(name, s, DIRSIZ);
00592   else {
00593     memmove(name, s, len);
00594     name[len] = 0;
00595   }
00596   while(*path == '/')
00597     path++;
00598   return path;
00599 }
00600 
00601 // Look up and return the inode for a path name.
00602 // If parent != 0, return the inode for the parent and copy the final
00603 // path element into name, which must have room for DIRSIZ bytes.
00604 static struct inode*
00605 namex(char *path, int nameiparent, char *name)
00606 {
00607   struct inode *ip, *next;
00608 
00609   if(*path == '/')
00610     ip = iget(ROOTDEV, ROOTINO);
00611   else
00612     ip = idup(proc->cwd);
00613 
00614   while((path = skipelem(path, name)) != 0){
00615     ilock(ip);
00616     if(ip->type != T_DIR){
00617       iunlockput(ip);
00618       return 0;
00619     }
00620     if(nameiparent && *path == '\0'){
00621       // Stop one level early.
00622       iunlock(ip);
00623       return ip;
00624     }
00625     if((next = dirlookup(ip, name, 0)) == 0){
00626       iunlockput(ip);
00627       return 0;
00628     }
00629     iunlockput(ip);
00630     ip = next;
00631   }
00632   if(nameiparent){
00633     iput(ip);
00634     return 0;
00635   }
00636   return ip;
00637 }
00638 
00639 struct inode*
00640 namei(char *path)
00641 {
00642   char name[DIRSIZ];
00643   return namex(path, 0, name);
00644 }
00645 
00646 struct inode*
00647 nameiparent(char *path, char *name)
00648 {
00649   return namex(path, 1, name);
00650 }
